author: itv.com
title: Mother critical of search efforts for son found dead in hospital grounds | UTV
text:
Play video The mother of a young man whose body lay undiscovered for 10 weeks in the grounds of the Ulster hospital believes that if the family had been allowed to help search for him at the time, he may have been saved.
James Fenton went missing from a mental health unit at the Ulster Hospital in July 2010.
His body lay for 10 weeks in the grounds unnoticed and just metres from the place where his family believed he would be safe.
On Monday James' mother told the coroner she believes if the family had been allowed to search for him at the time then maybe James could've been saved:
During the inquest Janice Fenton criticised the police's initial search for her son on the night he went missing.
A lawyer for the PSNI said however, that the search carried out was thorough.
An emotional Ms Fenton told the inquest nobody should be left to lie for 10 weeks in the open, saying “an animal wouldn't be left to lie that long".
In 2013, 12 police officers were disciplined over the handling of Mr Fenton’s disappearance.
The Police Ombudsman found a catalogue of mistakes.
The inquest heard in the hours leading up to his disappearance, Mr Fenton made several attempts on his life.
The 22-year-old lived with serious depression - abusing drugs and alcohol as a way of coping.
He was described as a mind in crisis - a young man in a dire place.
He was voluntarily admitted to the unit – a doctor told the inquest she had no reason to think he would try and escape and he was very grateful to be there getting help.
But Mr Fenton disappeared after climbing a fence that surrounded a garden area used for smoking.
Police at the time believed he may have been at Tor Bank special school or in Bangor with friends - searches were carried out.
Seventy days later and his body was found - 40 metres from the ward.
The inquest heard how this was not the first time patients had climbed the fence.
Figures were presented to the inquest by the family lawyer - between June 2009 and June 2010 – eight people had absconded - nearly one a month.
The inquest also heard from a nurse who was the last person to see James alive.
The coroner addressed him and explained how he understood there was a need for balance between security and custody - but Joe McCrisken said Mrs Fenton left the unit confident her son would be safe - at least until the morning and he wasn't.
James Fenton's family still don't know how he died or when he died.
The inquest is expected to last a week.
Last updated Mon 6 Feb 2017 courts Northern Ireland
